questions.question: What is the primary function of a calorimeter in a chemistry experiment?
options: To measure the amount of heat absorbed or released during a process.
To measure the change in atmospheric pressure.
To determine the molar mass of an unknown gas.
To speed up a reaction by acting as a catalyst.
questions.explanation: A calorimeter is an insulated device used to measure the heat exchange between a system and its surroundings (usually water).

questions.question: The amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one gram of a substance by one degree Celsius is called its:
questions.explanation: Specific heat capacity is a physical property that determines how much energy is needed to change a substance's temperature.

questions.question: What is the standard formula used to calculate heat transfer ($q$) in calorimetry?
questions.explanation: Heat ($q$) equals mass ($m$) times specific heat ($c$) times the change in temperature ($\Delta T$).

questions.question: In the equation $q = m c \Delta T$, what does the symbol $\Delta T$ represent?
options: The boiling point of the substance
questions.explanation: Delta ($ \Delta $) always signifies 'change', which is calculated as the final value minus the starting value.

questions.question: If a piece of hot metal is placed in a calorimeter filled with cool water, which statement is true regarding the heat flow?
options: The heat lost by the metal is equal to the heat gained by the water.
The water will lose heat to the metal.
Both the metal and the water will gain heat from the air.
The total energy of the system will increase significantly.
questions.explanation: According to the Law of Conservation of Energy, $q_{lost} = -q_{gained}$. The energy simply transfers from the hot object to the cooler one.

questions.question: Why is polystyrene (Styrofoam) often used to make 'coffee-cup' calorimeters?
options: It is a good insulator that minimizes heat exchange with the outside air.
It reacts with the chemicals to produce more heat.
It has a very high specific heat capacity itself.
It allows heat to escape quickly so the cup doesn't melt.
questions.explanation: Effective calorimetry requires preventing heat from leaking into or out of the environment, making insulation critical.

questions.question: Water has a high specific heat ($4.184$ J/g°C) compared to metals. This means water:
options: Requires more energy to change its temperature than metals do.
Heats up much faster than metals when the same energy is applied.
Has a very low boiling point.
Is a better conductor of heat than most metals.
questions.explanation: A high specific heat means a substance is resistant to temperature changes; it can absorb a lot of heat with only a small increase in temperature.

questions.question: In a calorimetry calculation, a positive value for $q$ indicates that the substance has:
questions.explanation: A positive $q$ means energy entered the substance, increasing its internal energy.

questions.question: How much heat is required to raise the temperature of $10$ g of water by $10$°C? (Specific heat of water = $4.18$ J/g°C)
questions.explanation: Using $q = m c \Delta T$: $10 \text{ g} \times 4.18 \text{ J/g°C} \times 10 \text{°C} = 418 \text{ J}$.

questions.question: A 'Bomb Calorimeter' is specifically used to measure the heat of ______ at constant volume.
questions.explanation: Bomb calorimeters are heavy-duty devices used to measure the energy content of fuels and foods by burning them in a high-pressure oxygen environment.
